conclusion: Consider effects of gravity, collision, and deflection to determine where the blue ball will collide and land.
The blue ball (A) is initially positioned above the blocks.
Gravity will pull the ball downward.
The ball will first collide with the block directly below it, which appears to be the block on the left side of the image.
Upon collision with the first block, the ball will be deflected; direction depends on angle and elasticity.
Given the arrangement of the blocks, the ball is likely to be deflected towards the adjacent blocks.
If deflected to the right, the ball may collide with the block on the right side of the image.
If deflected to the left, the ball may collide with the block on the left side of the image.
After colliding with one or more blocks, the ball will eventually come to rest.
The final position will depend on the cumulative effects of the collisions and deflections.
Given the arrangement of the blocks, the ball is likely to end up near the center of the group of blocks or slightly to the right.

The blue ball (A) will most likely collide with the block on the left side first, then be deflected towards the block on the right side, and eventually come to rest near the center of the group of blocks or slightly to the right.
